repnme.cdata!: India - Madras Water Supply and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The key lessons learned during
            preparation include: 1) Where the Borrower is reluctant to
            undertake policy reform in certain key areas, it is
            appropriate for the Bank to seek some actions prior to
            appraisal. 2) In accordance with current Bank practice, this
            project should have been appraised only when fully prepared
            in terms of technical studies, engineering design,
            procurement procedures and implementation plan. 3) As agreed
            delegations of authority to the implementing agency for
            procurement were later unilaterally withdrawn by Government
            of Tamil Nadu they should have been backed by covenants to
            ensure they remained in place. The lessons drawn from
            implementation include: a) The Bank should have provided
            above-average levels of supervision support to a first-time
            Borrower in the first few years of implementation. b) The 8
            years of implementation from effectiveness to closing was
            possibly responsible for the development of a somewhat
            relaxed approach to preparation and implementation
            activities, and a shorter period might have engendered a
            greater sense of Borrower urgency. c) An implementation plan
            should have been prepared with performance indicators and
            regular reporting. d) The considerable institutional and
            policy strengthening achievements in the areas of
            conjunctive use of water, groundwater legislation, and cost
            recovery reflected the attention given to these issues.
